docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT, LAND AND ENVIRONMENT COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.5 –40.8]

heading.title: PART 40 ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR ENFORCING JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS OF THE SUPREME COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.1 –40.8]
DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT, LAND AND ENVIRONMENT COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.5 –40.8]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 40 ADDITIONAL MEASURES FOR ENFORCING JUDGMENTS AND ORDERS OF THE SUPREME COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.1 –40.8]
DIVISION 2 PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT, LAND AND ENVIRONMENT COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.5 –40.8]

leg:heading.title: PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE SUPREME COURT, LAND AND ENVIRONMENT COURT AND DISTRICT COURT [rr 40.5 –40.8]

p.text: [Heading am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[5], effective 28 January 2008]

This Division applies to judgments and orders of the Supreme Court, the Land and Environment Court or the District Court (in this Division referred to simply as judgments), and so applies in addition to the provisions of Part 8 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.

Under the District Court Act 1973, the powers conferred on the Supreme Court, the Land and Environment Court by this Division may also be exercised by the District Court in relation to certain judgments and orders of the District Court.
[r 40.5 am Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[6], effective 28 January 2008]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.6] r 40.6 Doing or abstaining from doing an act (cf SCR Part 42, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Doing or abstaining from doing an act (cf SCR Part 42, rule 6)

p.text: This rule applies in the following circumstances:
if:
a judgment requires a person to do an act within a time specified in the judgment, and
the person fails to do the act within that time or, if that time is extended or abridged, within that time as extended or abridged,
if:
a judgment requires a person to do an act forthwith, or forthwith on a specified event, and
the person fails to do the act as so required,
if:
a judgment requires a person to abstain from doing an act, and
the person disobeys the judgment,
but does not apply to a judgment for the payment of money (including a judgment for the payment of money into court).
In circumstances to which this rule applies, a judgment may be enforced by one or more of the following means:
committal of the person bound by the judgment,
sequestration of the property of the person bound by the judgment,
if the person bound by the judgment is a corporation:
committal of any officer of the corporation, and
sequestration of the property of any officer of the corporation.
Legislation cited in [40.6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 130, s 131.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 36.5.

Section 130 of the CPA prohibits enforcement of a judgment for the payment of money by committal or attachment. But s 131 of the CPA preserves the power to commit as a sanction for contempt. Under the present rule committal is a permissible mode of enforcement of judgments both (i) where the person bound has failed to comply with notice of a judgment (see r 40.7) and the judgment requires compliance either forthwith or within a “specified time” and (ii) where the person has disobeyed a judgment requiring them to abstain from particular conduct. (Enforcement in the former case was referred to as “attachment” and in the latter as “committal”: see D v A & Co [1900] 1 Ch 484 .) A judgment requiring compliance “forthwith” is not an order requiring compliance within a “specified time” for the purpose of the present rule. But such an order falls within r 40.6(1)(b) and, in any event, r 36.5 permits the court to fix the time for compliance with any judgment or order. See Scott v Riley [2007] NSWSC 560; BC200704687 and Nevill & Ashe, “Equity Proceedings with Precedents (NSW)” for a form of warrant for committal.

level.toc-caption: [40.6.10] Committal of directors of a corporation — enforcement against

heading.title: Committal of directors of a corporation — enforcement against

p.text: The power to proceed against an officer of a corporation does not directly enforce the judgment, but is directed towards obtaining the cooperation of the officer in causing the corporation to comply with its obligations under the judgment: ANS Nominees Pty Ltd v Beverly Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd [1979] 2 NSWLR 875 per Needham J,. Consistent with that analysis, judgment creditors cannot proceed against an officer unless they are also in a position to enforce the judgment against the corporation itself: Iberian Trust Ltd v Founders Trust and Investment Co Ltd [1932] 2 KB 87 ; Benabo v William Jay & Partners Ltd [1941] Ch 52; [1940] 4 All ER 196 ; ANS Nominees Pty Ltd v Beverly Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd , above (defendant company in liquidation). Because of this requirement the two remedies are often said to be alternative. However, subject to the limitation against double recovery, there is in fact nothing to prevent enforcement proceedings being taken simultaneously against both the corporation and its officers: Phonographic Performance Ltd v Amusement Caterers (Peckham) Ltd [1963] 3 All ER 493 ; ANS Nominees Pty Ltd v Beverly Manufacturing Co Pty Ltd , above.

Breach of an undertaking may be punished by committal in the same way as the breach of an injunction: Biba Ltd v Stratford Investments Ltd [1973] Ch 281; [1972] 3 All ER 1041 ; Gandolfo v Gandolfo [1981] 1 QB 359; London & Birmingham Railway v Grand Junction Canal Co (1835) 1 Ry & Can Cas 224; Milburn v Newton Colliery Ltd (1908) 52 Sol Jo 317 ; Greys v Greys (Midlands) Ltd (1952) 70 RPC 25; Redwing Ltd v Redwing Forest Products Ltd (1947) 177 LT 387; 64 RPC 67 ; even if the undertaking is for a sum of money: Spindler v Balog (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 391 ; Re Launder (1908) 98 LT 554 . No notice of this undertaking need be given to the person sought to be committed: D v A & Co [1900] 1 Ch 484 ; Re Launder, above; but see now r 40.7(2). Directors of a corporation which breaches an undertaking to a court may be proceeded against under the present rule whether or not they personally aided and abetted the corportation’s breach: Biba Ltd v Stratford Investments Ltd , above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.7] r 40.7 Service of copy of judgment before committal or sequestration (cf SCR Part 42, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Service of copy of judgment before committal or sequestration (cf SCR Part 42, rule 8)

p.text: A judgment is not enforceable by committal or sequestration unless:
a sealed copy of the judgment is served personally on the person bound by the judgment, and

if the judgment requires the person to do an act within a specified time, the sealed copy is so served within that time or, if that time is extended or abridged, within that time as extended or abridged.

If the person is a corporation, the judgment is not enforceable by committal of an officer of the corporation or by sequestration of the property of an officer of the corporation unless, in addition to service under subrule (1):
a sealed copy of the judgment is served personally on the officer, and
if the judgment requires the corporation to do an act within a specified time, the sealed copy is so served before that time expires.
The sealed copy of the judgment must bear a notice (naming the persons concerned) that the person served is liable to imprisonment or to sequestration of property:
where the judgment requires the person to do an act within a specified time, if the person fails to do the act within that time, or
where the judgment requires the person to do an act forthwith or forthwith on a specified event, if the person fails to do the act as so required, or
where the judgment requires the person to abstain from doing an act, if the person disobeys the judgment.
If a person liable to committal or sequestration by way of enforcement of a judgment has notice of the judgment:
by being present when the judgment is directed to be entered, or
by being notified of the terms of the judgment, whether by telephone, telegram or otherwise,
the judgment may be enforced against that person by committal or sequestration without service having been effected in accordance with this rule.
The court may dispense with service under this rule.
This rule does not apply to a committal or sequestration arising from a failure to comply with the requirements of a subpoena.
[subr (6) insrt Gaz 87 of 6 July 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 6 July 2007]

The notice required by r 40.7(3) carries the warning that committal or sequestration may follow failure to comply with the relevant order. This is consistent with the proposition that the court’s enforcement powers are enlivened whenever a party fails to comply with orders, even if the non-compliance is not deliberate or contumacious: Heatons Transport (St Helens) Ltd v Transport and General Workers Union [1973] AC 15 ; Spokes v Banbury Board of Health (1865) LR 1 Eq 42; Pratt v Inman (1889) 43 Ch D 175; [1886–90] All ER Rep Ext 1030 ; Stancomb v Trowbridge Urban District Council [1910] 2 Ch 190 ; Steiner Products Ltd v Willy Steiner Ltd [1966] 2 All ER 387; [1966] 1 WLR 986 ; Trade Practices Commission v CG Smith Pty Ltd (1978) 30 FLR 368; (1978) ATPR ¶40-059 . However, neither committal nor sequestration is appropriate where the failure to comply is accidental or otherwise unintentional: Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union v Mudginberri Station Pty Ltd (1986) 161 CLR 98 at 113; 66 ALR 577; BC8601455 . Where disobedience is of the requisite kind the rule permits committal of the individual bound and, in certain circumstances, a director of a corporation: see r 40.6(2)(c)(i).

Where the failure to comply with a judgment or order is not intentional the court may declare that there has been a breach of the judgment or order and allow an opportunity for obeying the order: Bonshaw Freehold Gold Mining Co v Prince of Wales Co (1868) 5 WW & A’B (E) 148. Costs may be awarded against the defaulting party, either on the ordinary, or a more generous basis: Attorney-General v Walthamstow Urban District Council (1895) 11 TLR 533 ; Lee v Aylesbury Urban District Council (1902) 19 TLR 106 ; Stancomb v Trowbridge Urban District Council [1910] 2 Ch 190 ; GCT (Management) Ltd v Laurie Marsh Group Ltd [1973] RPC 432 . If the failure to comply is intentional, but the nature of the order and the non-compliance are such that the consequences of the failure to comply cannot be effectively or completely remedied, the court may exercise its contempt powers to impose a punishment for the purpose of vindicating the authority of the court: Witham v Holloway (1995) 183 CLR 525; 131 ALR 401; [1995] HCA 3; BC9506443 ; and see further [SCR Pt 55.13.1]–[SCR Pt 55.13.2] .

level.toc-caption: [40.7.10] Service — not required where terms of judgment known

heading.title: Service — not required where terms of judgment known

p.text: The present rule does not require service of a notice complying with UCPR r 40.7(3) where the person concerned has knowledge or notice of the terms of the order — either as a consequence of being present when the orders were made, or as a result of a later communication: Anderson v Hassett [2007] NSWSC 1310; BC200709923 at [9] (person present when orders made and subsequently provided with a copy); Allen v Allen (1885) 10 PD 187; 54 LJP 77; 33 WR 826 ; Re Suarez; Suarez v Suarez [1918] 1 Ch 176; [1916–17] All ER Rep 641 ; McDonnell v Novello [2006] NSWSC 1186; BC200609199 at [22] (inconclusive evidence of service by fax — notice not established).

If the obligation to be enforced derives from an undertaking, evidence that the undertaking was given will usually suffice to demonstrate sufficient knowledge by the affected person to dispense with any further requirement for service: Hussain v Hussain [1986] 1 All ER 961; [1986] 2 WLR 801; [1986] Fam 134 (undertaking by parties); Ronson Products Ltd v Ronson Furniture Ltd [1966] Ch 603; [1966] 2 All ER 381 (undertaking by corporation — no service required on directors present in court when formal orders were made) not following Redwing Ltd v Redwing Forest Products Ltd (1947) 177 LT 387; 64 RPC 67 on this point. Similarly, if the relevant obligation derives from orders that were made by consent, that circumstance may justify satisfaction that the terms were actually and sufficiently known: Duncan-Strelec v Tate [2008] NSWSC 1145; BC200809514 (inferred that consent orders were known to company controllers); Leung v Good Friend Development Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 142; BC200800992 .

UCPR 40.7(5) specifically permits the court to dispense with the requirement for service of a complying notice of the judgment or order. But the nature of the committal power requires careful use of the power to dispense with service: Drummoyne Municipal Council v Lewis [1974] 1 NSWLR 655 ; Clifford v Middleton [1974] VR 737 at 739, 741 . A very important factor in deciding whether to exercise the discretion to dispense with personal service is whether the substantial purpose of the notice requirement has otherwise been satisfied. The power should not be exercised against a person who did not know that imprisonment was a potential consequence of breach of the order: NCR Australia Pty Ltd v Credit Connection Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1118; BC200509669 .

Where the affected person has evaded service, a committal order may be made even if there was no adequate compliance with the substance of the rule: Doyle v Commonwealth (1985) 156 CLR 510 at 517; 60 ALR 567; 59 ALJR 665; BC8501102 ; Gordon v Gordon [1946] P 99 at 103; [1946] 1 All ER 247; (1946) 62 TLR 217 , and Taylor v Whelan [1962] VR 306 at 307 ; Ronowska v Kus (No 2) [2012] NSWSC 817 , Pembroke J at [29]–[33], [58] (person with actual knowledge of the terms of the order — deliberate disobedience and avoidance of service).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 40.8] r 40.8 Substituted performance (cf SCR Part 42, rule 9)

p.text: If a judgment requires a person to do an act and the person does not do the act, the court:
may direct that the act be done by a person appointed by the court, and
may order the person to pay the costs incurred pursuant to the direction.
